(The file is copied as non-executable there by eclipse. Making it executable 
doesn't change the original error, I had already checked that.)

Linux doesn't require that shared libraries be marked executable (although I
thought for sure the osgi stuff did so, I'll look into that).

The error "No such file or directory" when the library exists usually occurs
because a dependency cannot be found, so I expected to see some unsatisfied link
errors.  It looks like everything is found though.  Are you maybe using a 64-bit
VM, but using a 32-bit eclipse?  This would cause it to use a different runtime
linker...

Yes, it is. I called it with powerpc32 so I thought it wouldn't matter, but  
the VM of course stays 64bit.  
  
I guess this is INVALID, then?

Do you have a 32 bit VM to try with?  Is Eclipse working for you yet? :)

I am not as familiar with the ppc systems.  For x86-64, some users have both 32
bit and 64 bit versions of GTK+ installed, and can use either the 64 or 32 bit
versions of Eclipse.  The application, VM, and libraries all must be the same
for things to work.  Bug 73839 is requesting that we do a build of Eclipse for
64 bit PPC.  I am not sure how common this is, it seems that most Linux-PPC
distros are 32 bit.

Thoughts?

With a 32bit VM the binary version is working.  
  
Thanks for your help.
